channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for OH
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for OH

item.title: Report E-2024070147
item.description:
Report E-2024070147

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-10T18:16:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-06
  • City: Brewster
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: John Vergis
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The WLE Brewster Yard Car Inspector found tank car PROX 44241 leaking from the bottom outlet valve. He called the Brewster Yardmaster who then called myself, John Vergis, Hazardous Materials Officer for the WLE. I came out to look at the car and found that the bottom outlet valve of the car was indeed leaking through the valve cap. The valve handle was in the closed position and would not close any more. It was a disengaging ball valve. I removed the seal from the valve handle #1880761 and the valve stem #1880762, so that I could try to cycle the valve to see if I could get the leak to stop. I could not get the valve to move in either direction either with the valve handle or with a pipe wrench directly on the valve stem. I tried to tighten the valve cap with a 36" pipe wrench but I could not get it any more tight and the leak would not stop. I put containment under the leaking valve and called Specialized Professional Services out of Washington , PA to come out to transload the car into another rail car. They arrived about 2300 hrs. to transload and completed the transload about 0600 the next morning. On Monday, 7-8-2024, SPSI came back out to clean the interior of the car so that it could go back to the MarkWest plant in Jewett to be repaired. After it was cleaned, I removed the bottom outlet cap and with a 36" pipe wrench, and a second person, we were able to get the valve to open. I looked up into the valve and saw that the nylon seal on the ball was shredded which was the cause of the leak.

item.title: Report E-2024070106
item.description:
Report E-2024070106

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-09T15:13:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-05
  • City: WEST CHESTER
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately 1/2 a cup of material released from one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and placed the spent absorbents into one (1) 5-gallon poly pail. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.description:
Report E-2024070079

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-08T18:15:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-27
  • City: KENT
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: When driver arrived at facility to drop trailer he opened door to check securement before dropping and noticed moisture on the floor by the pallet. Ther driver then put done absorbents and called the emergency number at 1900ET. There was no active leek at the time and the driver was able to contain the pallet as a precaution. The team showed up at 2000ET and repacked the container and the material was cleaned up and disposed of in the proper manor. the crew was complete at 2300ET.
